metadata.chief_complaint: abdominal pain with extensive family and social history

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi Aiden, hi Mom. I see Aiden's having stomach pain?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes, it's been going on for about two weeks now. Some days are worse than others. He's missed three days of school already.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Two weeks is a while. Aiden, can you point to where it hurts?

script.speaker: child
script.text: Here, around my belly button. Sometimes all over.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Is it there all the time or does it come and go?

script.speaker: child
script.text: It comes and goes. Sometimes really bad, then it's okay.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: What makes it worse? Eating? Certain foods?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: He says it's worse in the morning before school. And he's been eating less. He used to love breakfast but now he barely touches it.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any vomiting or diarrhea?

script.speaker: child
script.text: No.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Constipation? When was your last poop and was it normal?

script.speaker: child
script.text: Um, yesterday. It was normal I guess.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good. Any blood in your stool or black stools?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No, nothing like that.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Has he lost any weight?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I don't think so. Maybe a pound or two? It's hard to tell.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I want to ask about family history. Any digestive problems in the family?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Actually yes. His dad has Crohn's disease. He was diagnosed in his twenties. And my sister has celiac disease.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's helpful to know. Anyone else with GI issues? Ulcers, colitis?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: His grandfather, my dad, had colon cancer. But he was in his seventies.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay. I appreciate you sharing all that. Let me ask about what's going on at home and school. Any big changes recently?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Well... his dad and I are getting divorced. We told the kids about a month ago. And he just started at a new school this year because we moved.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's a lot of change. How's the new school going, Aiden?

script.speaker: child
script.text: It's okay. I don't really know anyone yet.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: He's had trouble making friends. His old school was small and he knew everyone. This one is much bigger.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That can be really hard. Do you like your teachers?

script.speaker: child
script.text: They're fine. I just... I don't like going.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Does your stomach hurt more on school days or weekends?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Now that you mention it, he does seem better on weekends. I thought it was because he's resting more.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me examine his belly.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Aiden, lie back for me. I'm going to press on your tummy. Tell me if anything hurts.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: His abdomen is soft, no masses or tenderness. No guarding or rebound. That's reassuring.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Here's what I'm thinking. Given the family history of Crohn's and celiac, I do want to run some blood tests to screen for those. We'll check a CBC, inflammatory markers, and celiac antibodies.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay. What if those come back normal?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: If the labs are normal and his exam is normal, which it is today, then we're likely dealing with functional abdominal pain. That's real pain, but it's related to stress and how the gut and brain communicate.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: So you think the divorce and new school could be causing this?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It's very possible. The gut is incredibly sensitive to stress, especially in kids. That doesn't mean the pain isn't real, it absolutely is. But the treatment might involve more than just medication.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Like what?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Depending on the labs, we might consider a referral to a therapist who works with kids going through transitions. Sometimes addressing the anxiety helps the stomach.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: He's already seeing the school counselor once a week.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's a great start. Let's get these labs and go from there. If the celiac screen or inflammatory markers are elevated, we'll refer to GI. Otherwise, we'll focus on stress management and see if things improve.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you for taking this seriously. I was worried you'd just say it's in his head.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Never. His pain is real. We just need to figure out what's driving it. Aiden, we're going to help you feel better, okay?

script.speaker: child
script.text: Okay.
